$('.article-top-widget').on('click', '.ati-toggle-trigger', function () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div     <li><a class=\"addthis_button_compact\"><span>More</span></a></li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                    <div id=\"MobileMicrositeSearch\" class=\"mobile-microsite-search\">\r\n                        <label for=\"mobile-navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">Navbar Search Filter</label>\r\n class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-account-dropdown\">\r\n        <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                <a href=\"\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin dummy-link js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n                <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1 individual-menu\">\r\n                    <li class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            University of Utah\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1\">\r\n                            <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nUniversity of Utah\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f484%2f3%2f3879%2f5290335\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\" >This issue</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" selected=&quot;selected&quot;>All  Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</option>\r\n\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                                    <optgroup label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=134762048 id=\"134762048\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a new sample of galaxy-scale strong gravitational lens candidates, selected from 904\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> of Data Release 4 of the Kilo-Degree Survey, i.e. the \u2018Lenses in the Kilo-Degree Survey\u2019 (LinKS) sample. We apply two convolutional neural networks (ConvNets) to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }88\\,000$|</span> colour\u2013magnitude-selected luminous red galaxies yielding a list of 3500 strong lens candidates. This list is further downselected via human inspection. The resulting LinKS sample is composed of 1983 rank-ordered targets classified as \u2018potential lens candidates\u2019 by at least one inspector. Of these, a high-grade subsample of 89 targets is identified with potential strong lenses by all inspectors. Additionally, we present a collection of another 200 strong lens candidates discovered serendipitously from various previous ConvNet runs. A straightforward application of our procedure to future <em>Euclid</em> or Large Synoptic Survey Telescope data can select a sample of \u223c3000 lens candidates with less than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent expected false positives and requiring minimal human intervention.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: elliptical and lenticular, cD&quot;\">galaxies: elliptical and lenticular, cD</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=134762050 id=\"134762050\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lenses<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> are composite systems where a massive foreground object (e.g. a galaxy or a cluster) creates multiple images of one or more higher redshift sources (e.g. galaxies or quasars). Strong lenses are useful for a wide range of cosmological and astrophysical studies (Schneider, Ehlers\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Falco <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Schneider, Kochanek\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). For example, they can provide cosmological constraints on the dark energy equation of state (Collett\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Auger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Cao et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) and precision measurements of the Hubble constant (Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib136\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib136\" data-open=\"bib136\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The information obtained from strong lensing also allows us to study the mass distribution in the inner regions of galaxies: e.g. the fraction of dark matter in their central regions (Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Jiang\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Cardone\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Tortora <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Grillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Tortora et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib143\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib143\" data-open=\"bib143\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Ruff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), the slope of their inner mass density profile (Treu\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Koopmans <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib145\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib145\" data-open=\"bib145\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib121\" data-open=\"bib121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Cao et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Li, Shu\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Wang <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and their dark matter substructures (More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Vegetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib155\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib155\" data-open=\"bib155\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Nierenberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Besides studying dark matter, strong lenses allow us to place constraints on the stellar initial mass function (IMF) when combined with dynamical and stellar population synthesis analyses (Ferreras et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib146\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib146\" data-open=\"bib146\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib130\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib130\" data-open=\"bib130\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib131\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib131\" data-open=\"bib131\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Brewer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Posacki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>; Leier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Vernardos <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib156\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib156\" data-open=\"bib156\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Finally, strong lenses can act as a \u2018cosmic telescope\u2019, providing a magnified view of otherwise unresolved background sources (e.g. Impellizzeri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib137\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib137\" data-open=\"bib137\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Deane et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib148\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib148\" data-open=\"bib148\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Mason et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Salmon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Kelly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The above-listed studies have typically been carried out using samples of tens to maximally about a hundred massive lens galaxies (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|${M}_\\star \\gtrsim 10^{11}\\,{\\rm M}_\\odot$|\u2060</span>), and are often limited to redshifts <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0\u2272\u00a00.5 and/or are inhomogeneously selected. Current results are therefore often limited by sample size or cosmic variance. Creating more substantial, homogeneously selected samples of gravitational lenses, which extend to lower mass galaxies and higher redshifts, will reduce the effects of \u2018small-number statistics\u2019 and allow an improved study of lens galaxies as a function of galaxy properties and evolutionary state. In particular, Vegetti\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Koopmans (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib154\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib154\" data-open=\"bib154\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) estimate that it is possible to compute subhalo mass fractions of lens galaxies to a level of \u22720.1\u00a0per\u00a0cent with only \u223c50 lens systems. With the same number of lenses, it is possible to reach a\u00a0per\u00a0cent level precision in estimating their mass density slopes (Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Therefore a much larger number of galaxy-scale lenses can improve the outcome from these analyses and enable one to conduct a proper statistical comparison with the results obtained from lens simulations (e.g. Li et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Xu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Mukherjee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Moreover, the precision of the value of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> can be improved to the level of a few per\u00a0cent when studying a sample of about 40 strong lenses with measured time delays (Jee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Shajib, Treu\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Collecting large samples of strong lenses, furthermore, giving us better access to the high-redshift Universe and increases the probability of discovering double Einstein ring (Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) and other \u2018exotic\u2019 lenses (e.g. Tu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib149\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib149\" data-open=\"bib149\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Cooray et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Brammer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Tanaka et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib138\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib138\" data-open=\"bib138\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Moreover, samples of homogeneously selected strong lenses are needed to characterize the selection function of a strong lens survey, allowing to map measurements carried out on strong lenses back to the general population of galaxies. We refer the reader to the LSST Science Book (LSST Science Collaborations <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and the <em>Euclid</em> Strong Lensing white paper (Euclid Strong Lensing team, in preparation) for a more detailed discussion of future scientific applications of strong gravitational lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The largest homogeneously selected sample of confirmed strong lenses is the Sloan Lens ACS Survey (SLACS; Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), which yielded more than a hundred spectroscopically confirmed strong lenses with complete redshift information and high-resolution imaging follow-up (with e.g. the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> and Keck Observatory Adaptive Optics). In total, all lens surveys combined have produced up to a thousand highly likely<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> gravitational lens candidates (e.g. Browne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Faure et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib147\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib147\" data-open=\"bib147\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Brownstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013a</a>; Stark et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib135\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib135\" data-open=\"bib135\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Ongoing wide-field optical\u2013infrared (IR) surveys are expected to make the next giant step forward by yielding thousands of new lenses (Collett <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Petrillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The first new lens candidates have already been discovered (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Hartley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Petrillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Jacobs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib132\" data-open=\"bib132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib159\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib159\" data-open=\"bib159\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) in the Kilo-Degree Survey (KiDS; de Jong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), in the Hyper Suprime-Cam Subaru Strategic Program (HSC; Miyazaki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), and in the Dark Energy Survey (DES; The Dark Energy Survey Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib141\" data-open=\"bib141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). Similarly large samples are expected from deep sub-mm observations by e.g. the <em>Herschel Telescope</em> (Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), the South Pole Telescope (SPT; Carlstrom et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), and the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA).<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> These telescopes have already uncovered hundreds of new lens candidates (Vieira et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Within the next decade, \u223c10<sup>5</sup> strong lenses are expected to be found in future surveys (Oguri\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Pawase et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Collett <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; McKean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) utilizing e.g. ESA\u2019s <em>Euclid</em> mission (Laureijs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST; LSST Science Collaborations <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), and the Square Kilometre Array (SKA).<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> In particular, these surveys will allow lower mass and higher redshift lenses to be found, thanks to their deeper and higher angular resolution observations. Moreover, it will become possible to follow up promising targets at an even higher angular resolution with ALMA and the European Extremely Large Telescope (E-ELT). A future SKA-very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) facility could, in addition, investigate milliarcsecond angular scales of the lensed images for the effects of dark matter line-of-sight and subhaloes (Spingola et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib129\" data-open=\"bib129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), enabling one to study small deviations from the smooth mass model of the lens.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lenses are scarce objects within the total population of galaxies. In current surveys, of the order of one strong lens exists per few hundred to a thousand galaxies. This number strongly depends on galaxy mass and selection criteria, with the number of lenses peaking around <em>M</em>*-galaxies for source-selected samples and at larger masses when lenses are selected as luminous red galaxies (LRGs). Their rarity makes it essential to develop robust lens-finder algorithms and deploy them in streamlined data processing pipelines. This end-to-end automation will drastically reduce, and possibly prevent entirely, the need for future visual inspection of millions of potential lens candidates (e.g. Lenzen, Schindler\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Scherzer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Horesh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Alard <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Estrada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Seidel\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Kubo\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Dell\u2019Antonio <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Joseph et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Maturi, Mizera\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Seidel <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Brault\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Gavazzi <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Chan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Hartley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Jacobs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Petrillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib132\" data-open=\"bib132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Stapelberg, Carrasco\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Maturi <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In light of such an automation strategy, we recently developed (Petrillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and more recently improved upon (Petrillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), a new convolutional neural network (ConvNet) lens-finder algorithm. The objective in this paper is to report on how we use ConvNets in an automated lens-search pipeline, and report on the results of applying these networks to galaxies selected from \u223c900\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> of KiDS Data Release 4. The core result that we present is an automatically selected sample of 3500 rank-ordered strong lens candidates. From this ConvNet pre-selected sample, several subsamples of higher confidence candidates are distilled through human visual inspection.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we provide a brief introduction to KiDS, the imaging and catalogue data that are used in this paper. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, we explain how we select a subsample of intrinsically luminous (red) galaxies from the colour\u2013magnitude diagram of KiDS galaxies, as well as the methodology used to identify gravitational lens candidates within that colour\u2013magnitude-selected subsample. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, we present the gravitational lens candidates found from the most conservative sample selection. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>, we apply the networks to a wider selection of galaxies \u2013 inherently limited only in their apparent brightness \u2013 to examine the efficiency of the algorithm in extremely data-heavy regimes such as those expected from future astronomical surveys, such as with <em>Euclid</em> and LSST, which may also have restricted colour information. In the same section, we also present a \u2018bonus sample\u2019 of inhomogeneously selected lens candidates that were identified serendipitously during various past experiments in the development of the final ConvNets. Lastly, in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>, we summarize our main conclusions.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=134762058 id=\"134762058\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 DATA FROM THE KILO-DEGREE SURVEY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The Kilo-Degree Survey (KiDS; de Jong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) is an ESO public survey carried out with the OmegaCAM wide-field imager (Kuijken <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) mounted on the VLT Survey Telescope (VST; Capaccioli\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Schipani <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) at the Paranal Observatory in Chile. The telescope, camera, and survey have been designed to obtain images with subarcsecond seeing and homogeneous image quality both across the full field of view and throughout the survey execution. In this way the survey yields a large and homogeneous galaxy sample. The size and homogeneity of this sample are required for the surveys primary science drivers, which include placing strong constraints on both the distribution of matter across cosmic time and the cosmological parameters of the universe through weak-lensing measurements; the subtle distortions introduced in galaxy shapes by cosmic shear (e.g. Hildebrandt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). At the same time, the combined power of the survey\u2019s superb image quality and wide area makes KiDS optimal for strong-lensing studies (Napolitano et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Petrillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib132\" data-open=\"bib132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). OmegaCAM has a 1\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> field of view, with pixels that have an angular scale of 0.21\u00a0arcsec, and KiDS will survey a total of \u223c1350\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> in four optical bands (<em>u, g, r</em>, and <em>i</em>) by the end of observations in 2019. The best seeing observations are reserved for the <em>r</em> band, with the survey exhibiting median point spread function (PSF) full width at half-maximum (FWHM) values of 1.0, 0.8, 0.65, and 0.85\u00a0arcsec in the <em>u, g, r</em>, and <em>i</em> bands, respectively. The survey depths per-band, as determined by the 5\u03c3 limiting magnitudes within a 2\u00a0arcsec circular aperture, are 24.2, 25.1, 25.0, and 23.7 in the <em>u, g, r</em>, and <em>i</em> bands, respectively (de Jong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we make use of 904 tiles<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> that form a subset of the KiDS Data Release 4 (KiDS ESO-DR4; Kuijken et\u00a0al., in preparation). The analysis performed uses imaging data, and derived products, produced within the Astro-WISE information system (Valentijn et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib153\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib153\" data-open=\"bib153\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; McFarland et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). We make use of the single-band and multiband catalogues of the KiDS-DR4.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=134762061 id=\"134762061\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 The \u2018full sample\u2019</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The target extraction and their associated photometry have been obtained using <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> (Bertin\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>). To optimize the initial lens searches, we pre-select a sample of luminous galaxies with reliable photometric data. We proceed in the following way. <ul class=\"alpha-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We select sources with a <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span><em>r</em>-band <span class=\"monospace\">flags</span> value &lt;4, thereby including only deblended sources and removing from the catalogue objects with incomplete or corrupted photometry, saturated pixels, or any other blending or extraction related problem.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We further reject galaxies in areas compromised by e.g. stellar diffraction spikes and reflection haloes, by selecting sources with the flag <span class=\"monospace\">ima_flags</span> set to zero for all the four KiDS bands.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We select sources with a Kron-like magnitude <span class=\"monospace\">mag_auto</span> in the <em>r</em>band below 20th\u00a0mag, in order to maximize the lensing cross-section (Schneider et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we select sources with flag <span class=\"small-caps\">2dphot</span> equal to 1 (as derived by the star\u2013galaxy separator software <span class=\"small-caps\">2dphot</span> (La Barbera et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) in order to select secure galaxies.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To reduce the contamination by stars further, we select only objects with a FWHM in <em>r</em> band greater than the 90\u00a0percentile range of the distribution of star-like objects within the same tile (those with <span class=\"monospace\">2dphot</span> equal to zero). We adopt this strategy to reach a suitable compromise between filtering out stars and not excising too many galaxies from the sample. This selection procedure results in a sample of nearly 1\u00a0million (specifically 930\u2009651) targets that we will refer to as the \u2018<em>full sample</em>\u2019 in the remainder of the paper.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=134762064 id=\"134762064\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 The luminous red galaxy sample</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Luminous red galaxies (LRGs; Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) are massive galaxies that, as a result, are more likely to exhibit strong lensing features than other classes of galaxies (see Turner, Ostriker\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Gott III <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib151\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib151\" data-open=\"bib151\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1984</a>; Fukugita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Chae <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; M\u00f6ller, Kitzbichler\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Natarajan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). We select LRGs from the <em>full sample</em>, defined earlier, using the low-redshift (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|</span>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.4) LRG colour\u2013magnitude selection of Eisenstein et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). We slightly adapt this selection to include fainter and bluer sources: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update250119_equ1\" content-id=\"update250119_equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n&amp;&amp;{|c_{\\rm {perp}}| &lt; 0.2,}\\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{r&lt; 14+c_{\\rm {par}}/0.3,} \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{\\text{where}}\\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{c_{\\rm {par}}=0.7(g-r)+1.2[(r-i)-0.18)],}\\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{c_{\\rm {perp}}=(r-i)-(g-r)/4.0-0.18.}\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>The magnitudes are <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span><span class=\"monospace\">mag_auto</span>. In this section, we chose to limit our analysis to the Astro-WISE single-band object detection catalogues. We determine the <em>u,g,r,i</em> photometry for each object using the individual <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span><span class=\"monospace\">mag_auto</span> measurements. As these measurements are made using slightly different centroids and the PSF varies significantly between bands, we do not expect this \u2018first-look\u2019 LRG selection methodology to be uniform. As our aim is not to compile a complete sample of LRGs, however, we do not expect this decision to impact our conclusions. We note that after the analysis for this project began, Vakili et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib152\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib152\" data-open=\"bib152\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) presented a sophisticated methodology to select LRG galaxies for clustering studies in KiDS-DR3. Future LinKS analyses will investigate adopting this LRG sample. Our selection results on a sample of 88\u2009327 sources, which we refer as the \u2018<em>LRG sample</em>\u2019 throughout the remainder of this paper. Note that our goal here is to select a reasonable number of massive (LRG) galaxies, without significant contamination by spiral galaxies, but that this sample need not strictly be purely LRGs. We find an average of 98 sources selected per tile with a standard deviation of \u223c43. This standard deviation is high, but expected given the \u2018first-look\u2019 methodology that we have adopted to compile this sample, in addition to the high levels of cosmic variance expected for this highly biased galaxy sample.</div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=134762066 id=\"134762066\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 SEARCHING FOR LENSES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To find gravitational lens candidates in KiDS imaging data, we use the ConvNets previously introduced by Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). These networks are significantly improved variants of the original ConvNet presented by Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). ConvNets (Fukushima <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>; LeCun et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) represent a state-of-the-art method of pattern recognition (Russakovsky et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The networks <em>learn</em> how to classify a diverse set of images during the so-called training phase, whereby labelled images are provided to the ConvNet. Its weight parameters are changed to minimize a pre-defined loss function, which expresses the difference between the labels of the images and the output values <em>p</em> (one for each image) of the ConvNet. For a more detailed introduction to ConvNets for finding lenses, we refer the interested reader to Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and to more general reviews by Schmidhuber (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), LeCun, Bengio\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Hinton (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), and Guo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To evaluate methods for identifying images of simulated gravitational lenses \u2013 in preparation for the <em>Euclid</em> mission (Metcalf et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) \u2013 recently an international challenge was organised. The results of this challenge demonstrated that ConvNets, collectively with Support Vector Machines (SVMs), are among the most promising methods for finding lens candidates currently available. As a proof of concept, ConvNets have been used to find new gravitational lens candidates by Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) in the KiDS DR3 and by Jacobs et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) in the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS) and in DES (Jacobs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In terms of methodology and target selection, our analysis differs from the work done by Spiniello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib132\" data-open=\"bib132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), who have focused their search exclusively on lensed quasar candidates in KiDS, by visual inspecting targets pre-selected using optical/IR colours. Lens candidates have also been found in the KiDS DR3 data by Hartley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), who trained a Gabor-SVM finder.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=134762070 id=\"134762070\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Training the convolutional neural networks</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We start by giving a brief synopsis of our ConvNets and the training procedure, as reported by Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Building on our experience, we choose to deploy two different ConvNets. One focuses on utilizing the best morphological information by taking the best seeing, i.e. <em>r</em> band, images as input. The other ConvNet exploits colour information in addition to morphological information by taking three-band RGB images as input. The RGB images are created with <span class=\"small-caps\">HumVI</span><sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup> (Marshall et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) using the <em>g, r</em>, and <em>i</em> bands. In both cases, the KiDS images have a size of 101\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0101\u00a0pixels (i.e. 20\u00a0\u00d7\u00a020\u00a0arcsec<sup>2</sup>) with the central pixel corresponding to the centre of the galaxy of interest. The ConvNets take these images and transform them into a single value, <em>p</em>, which can vary between 0 and 1. This value represents, to some degree (see e.g. Saerens, Latinne\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Decaestecker <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), the probability that the input image is a lens (see also Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a>). The input size of 20\u00a0\u00d7\u00a020\u00a0arcsec<sup>2</sup> is chosen to be sufficiently large as to enclose most galaxy-scale lens systems, and sufficiently small as to both avoid contamination by unrelated field objects and allow for a ConvNet with a practical memory requirement.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">7</a></sup></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use two classes of objects to train the ConvNets: (1) the <em>lenses</em> labelled with a 1.0, and (2) the <em>non-lenses</em>, labelled with a 0.0. <ol class=\"number\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the <em>lenses</em>, we use a set of \u223c6000 KiDS LRGs on which we superimpose simulated lensed images. The simulated lensed images (\u223c10<sup>6</sup> in number) are composed mostly of high-magnification rings, arcs, and quads. The gravitational lens mass distribution adopted in our simulations is assumed to be that of a singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE; Kormann, Schneider\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>) perturbed by additional Gaussian random field (GRF) fluctuations and an external shear. An elliptical S\u00e9rsic (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1968</a>) brightness profile is used to represent the lensed sources, and to which we add several small internal stellar structures (e.g. star formation regions, satellite galaxies), described by circular S\u00e9rsic profiles. For each background source, we extract magnitudes from the \u2018COSMOS\u2019 models provided by the code <span class=\"small-caps\">Le Phare</span> (Arnouts et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Ilbert et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) in order to simulate realistic <em>gri</em>-composite images. The lens and source parameters vary accordingly to the values in table\u00a01 of Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The non-lenses are a collection of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }12\\, 000$|</span> galaxies from KiDS. This sample is composed of a supersample of (a) the same LRGs used for the <em>lenses</em>; (b) randomly selected galaxies from the survey with a <em>r</em>-band magnitude brighter than 21; (c) \u2018false positives\u2019 (e.g. mergers, ring galaxies, etc.) from earlier ConvNets; and (d) a sample of galaxies that were visually classified as spirals from an on-going GalaxyZoo project (Willett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib158\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib158\" data-open=\"bib158\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Kelvin et\u00a0al., in preparation).</p></li></ol></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A more detailed description of the training sample preparation, the results of the training phase, and a detailed discussion of the performance of the ConvNets are presented in Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=134762074 id=\"134762074\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Application to the LRG sample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The ConvNets described in the previous subsection are both applied to the LRG sample, and only targets with <em>p</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.8 (returned from either of the ConvNets) are selected. This threshold is chosen to obtain a reasonable number of \u2018true positives\u2019 and, at the same time, not contaminate the sample with a large number of \u2018false positives\u2019. Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) present an extensive analysis of the performance of these ConvNets by choosing different <em>p</em>-value thresholds. With this threshold, the three-band ConvNet picks 1689 candidates, while the one-band ConvNet picks 2510 candidates. These numbers correspond to fractions of \u223c1.9 and \u223c2.8\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the LRG sample, respectively. We find a total of (exactly) 3500 unique candidates with <em>p</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.8 since 699 galaxies are common between both ConvNets. We refer to this sample of 3500 unique targets as the <em>ConvNet sample</em>.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">By setting the threshold value <em>p</em> to 0.8, however, we still expect the presence of many false positives in the <em>ConvNet sample</em> (\u223c90\u00a0per\u00a0cent; Petrillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). To validate the candidates, selected by the ConvNets, we conduct a visual inspection: seven of the authors of this paper \u2013 referred to as \u2018classifiers\u2019 \u2013 examine the 101\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0101\u00a0pixels RGB composite image, created with <span class=\"small-caps\">stiff</span><sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn8\" data-open=\"fn8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">8</a></sup> (Bertin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The classifiers have only three possible choices for each source being a lens: <em>Sure, Maybe</em>, and <em>No lens</em>. We translate each of these categories into a numerical value in the same way as was done by Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>): <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\begin{array}{l{@}{\\quad}l{@}{\\quad}l{@}{\\quad}l}\r\n\\text{A:} &amp; {\\rm Sure\\, lens} &amp; \\rm{10\\, points,}\\\\\r\n\\text{B:} &amp; {\\rm Maybe\\, lens} &amp; \\rm{4\\, points,}\\\\\r\n\\text{C:} &amp; {\\rm No\\, lens} &amp; \\rm{0\\, points.}\\end{array}\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div></div>As a result, the maximum score that any one galaxy candidate can obtain is 70, i.e. when all human classifiers think it is surely a lens. A histogram with the numerical results of the visual inspection is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. About \u223c57\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the initial 3500 candidates selected by the ConvNets (i.e. 1983 candidates) have at least one classifier selecting it as a <em>Sure lens</em> or <em>Maybe lens</em>. Only four candidates achieve the maximum score. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> presents the eight candidates that received the two highest scores, i.e. 64 and 70. Among them, there is one confirmed quad lens, J115252+004733 (bottom right-hand panel; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). It is worth noting that, within the full <em>ConvNet sample</em>, there are five confirmed lenses: J114330\u2212014427, J1025\u22120035 (Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), J085446\u2212012137 (Cabanac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), CSWA\u00a05 (Christensen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), and J115252+004733 (More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) classified with scores of 58, 22, 54, 24, 64, and 64, respectively (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). Naturally this means that none of these confirmed lenses were flagged as <em>Sure lens</em> by all classifiers. However, these sources are often confirmed as lensed through high angular resolution <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) follow-up, which makes it unsurprising that they are not classified as secure lenses in ground-based KiDS data. In the LRG sample there are other six known gravitational lenses that have not been identified by our ConvNets. However, the KiDS images of these objects do not exhibit striking lensing features and, thus, they are hardly recognizable as strong lenses.</div>                        <a id=\"134762077\" scrollto-destination=\"134762077\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/m_stz189fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&amp;Signature=prIbwROSgxPka7gdmrGrDYeMgi9cd8kV70bemvJoQikMphFTPulcENPtgYu1URmMjiatmC5s0yzE-e9rkGKWKWF9hFoXnNDHw4WJagD5Ht1Tf2i4lX2DI3b9nZpkttC1uwg3DyjyABtk3y50Ag-gFcHE7saZV4OOBpKHhOf9biGZW8SVTMVhFTSQ44EwbkdDk0hdU2RAQl-oCvyIsbKX7fI05aUCNP5Tk2DqpoivWQtkPSLwd~3qkNOb7g~Xy33Q0T4nyma5172FvrJZ2qErVC7Ve9wu13-a5UuXb3z6SFyYakQSnAtX60PAm0JekJyGNoCc4sVhwdz9Kx5AuJKC5w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Histogram of the numerical rankings from the visual inspection of 3500 targets, selected by the ConvNets, by seven human classifiers.
