The vertical bars correspond to the 16\u201384\u00a0percentile of the distributions.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/134762085/stz189fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"134762085\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/stz189fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&Signature=cWbmOeElp9eRXFemdV8kU~3v83nsolOwHZEf8NnUVwhi8rfhyzwQlEiIy-v2NA5ryghTJt8PRbhC768fmjqEwZekCtw6SR85Z3yjUPiv57rkfDvA2wPYdg1eHgFVfnULidfPo~GTQYZj-qtGXiwJkcfkAcQTYoNZFCQO1uRQDePKq9i~wfyiVVmpflN9IfR~HeWfqdvyfz5fbiukmKoGVsU77~Pt9ssi6lHPduQFYQMPXfXBduU0AtK21U8eEzA1w3Ofp~i1c-FtJ0y5olPT9QU1V2xmVemfGsauD6m3aZ7S0LrcGhGSQVpoNL91JpL3Y9np-UoniUqR0gyA7Yimyw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=134762085&ar=5290335&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Average of the <em>p</em>-values given by the two ConvNets divided in bins of the score of the visual inspection. The vertical bars correspond to the 16\u201384\u00a0percentile of the distributions.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/m_stz189fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&amp;Signature=qxNHCaLX07w~VRo9ST7gWwzcdO0m0yIiUg7KPBRjwXuTCRRi1dEemWQ0vLOvEvCPiZMcImMpshBvMSp39t4CflYiFwOE2iGcUvw4Aq3kVAqWBIigwPOyU3C7mz1SLLrIFsXIWcxl4Uk-AtTDcCurUSroj8S5ANBdUWmvr~E-yjOLQgc9YCCayNsi9phe8KE5XWkY2ThU3xLWrrJmTyI9F8qtErrZhdb67rzBKmmTSDMb9ECArpOdr~xW~g6h5woXtJ07GDnHhnYgAS0ZRj~xDQm7P1Q5Zwadhpbpb~oQpcbqk1rHirpjeMfVRqctfiftb~SukWYj9MgQbC219bB0mA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Average of the p-values given by the two ConvNets divided in bins of the score of the visual inspection. The vertical bars correspond to the 16\u201384\u00a0percentile of the distributions.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/134762085/stz189fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"134762085\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/stz189fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&Signature=cWbmOeElp9eRXFemdV8kU~3v83nsolOwHZEf8NnUVwhi8rfhyzwQlEiIy-v2NA5ryghTJt8PRbhC768fmjqEwZekCtw6SR85Z3yjUPiv57rkfDvA2wPYdg1eHgFVfnULidfPo~GTQYZj-qtGXiwJkcfkAcQTYoNZFCQO1uRQDePKq9i~wfyiVVmpflN9IfR~HeWfqdvyfz5fbiukmKoGVsU77~Pt9ssi6lHPduQFYQMPXfXBduU0AtK21U8eEzA1w3Ofp~i1c-FtJ0y5olPT9QU1V2xmVemfGsauD6m3aZ7S0LrcGhGSQVpoNL91JpL3Y9np-UoniUqR0gyA7Yimyw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=134762085&ar=5290335&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Average of the <em>p</em>-values given by the two ConvNets divided in bins of the score of the visual inspection. The vertical bars correspond to the 16\u201384\u00a0percentile of the distributions.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Even if there is no obvious inspection score below which the candidates are no longer reliable, we note the less observe an increase in the fraction of good candidates with increasing score. Therefore by defining some fiducial threshold for the visual-inspection score, above which one considers the targets as reliable candidates, we can investigate how the number of retrieved candidates (and the degree of contamination) vary as a function of the threshold set on the value of <em>p</em>. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> presents these correlations for all the ConvNet candidates and for a \u2018bona fide\u2019 subsample composed of targets with a visual-inspection score \u226528. This is a fiducial value of the score that corresponds to (a) <em>Maybe lens</em> given by all the classifiers or to (b) <em>Sure lens</em> given by two classifiers and <em>Maybe lens</em> from other two classifiers. In particular, in the left-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, we see how the number of retrieved candidates changes as a function of the value of <em>p</em>, greatly decreasing when <em>p</em> is approaching to 1. This change is more gentle in the case of the \u2018bona fide\u2019 sample. The right-hand panel shows that the fraction of \u2018bona fide\u2019 systems is increasing with <em>p</em>, reaching the lowest contamination degree when <em>p</em> is close to 1. This latter result confirms the correlation among the visual-inspection score and <em>p</em>, previously shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"134762087\" scrollto-destination=\"134762087\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/m_stz189fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&amp;Signature=K15DGwzeSSN1pLPkvsjSXFQkKDRnT1v3JfWv0aLItWa2o6TbW2Ibyia3Zim5MvAA3b7n328ij9myYqJ7HXyKLZOyYyBhAaed~G1m671DT7dLgEV9rG464Xx-jPinPosXCjq6Dp7NX-3x9f5O1sU8~Z-8Ix2L2ztHhDtgHbXjhsXZmDgffYCvKu9~D9lXx5bAUKKB2Itbc2JKrr36oN6qxPgNW2HOiCAPLcACit1yo5IQ22R2d1-ErdBlL74sawkyOObTiu~zwrMqV52L8HwbxkwDZ~j52rHh1nTmbieeClKBgwXyCnX-3aRhLhQ4T5iAPsPqRox~5Y~hdU1AK5MAEA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"On the left, we plot the number of targets retrieved by the two ConvNets and the number of \u2018bona fide\u2019 candidates as a function of the threshold of detection p. On the right, we show the percentage with respect to the total number of retrieved candidates as a function of the threshold of detection p.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/134762087/stz189fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"134762087\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/stz189fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&Signature=3hx9YbAcqaF11OMlLIbxy4q3hb0mVXj6Dj7260TnnCCy92juIw84lZjOKcnZmL8iXEVQXuc5wv8b8~wJtkmonzdW5atazGtgOuAW69p2Nqqhh8oEcQBmMs6U1eR1Ddfo7fytJJ7roL95JPqr9KjTgDiNB2v7gTldVUUQEzUCmJHh0gxgG1KDJa5W3V-fO~qW91W-LWL0IpmzScEyqTovLax1IB3Fh3Q1xTY9iAT9GlZ7Lm~NCHEkGWW5zcCKrrTkETNSWLDcWVZmeGs-B4y6VE6Maf7-pxSKE54dHyXqz2eW03NeZsTbWBBX72kqwFggKL~HxZhKmSZLWbngtTTzdA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=134762087&ar=5290335&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">On the left, we plot the number of targets retrieved by the two ConvNets and the number of \u2018bona fide\u2019 candidates as a function of the threshold of detection <em>p</em>. On the right, we show the percentage with respect to the total number of retrieved candidates as a function of the threshold of detection <em>p</em>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/m_stz189fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&amp;Signature=K15DGwzeSSN1pLPkvsjSXFQkKDRnT1v3JfWv0aLItWa2o6TbW2Ibyia3Zim5MvAA3b7n328ij9myYqJ7HXyKLZOyYyBhAaed~G1m671DT7dLgEV9rG464Xx-jPinPosXCjq6Dp7NX-3x9f5O1sU8~Z-8Ix2L2ztHhDtgHbXjhsXZmDgffYCvKu9~D9lXx5bAUKKB2Itbc2JKrr36oN6qxPgNW2HOiCAPLcACit1yo5IQ22R2d1-ErdBlL74sawkyOObTiu~zwrMqV52L8HwbxkwDZ~j52rHh1nTmbieeClKBgwXyCnX-3aRhLhQ4T5iAPsPqRox~5Y~hdU1AK5MAEA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"On the left, we plot the number of targets retrieved by the two ConvNets and the number of \u2018bona fide\u2019 candidates as a function of the threshold of detection p. On the right, we show the percentage with respect to the total number of retrieved candidates as a function of the threshold of detection p.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/134762087/stz189fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"134762087\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/stz189fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&Signature=3hx9YbAcqaF11OMlLIbxy4q3hb0mVXj6Dj7260TnnCCy92juIw84lZjOKcnZmL8iXEVQXuc5wv8b8~wJtkmonzdW5atazGtgOuAW69p2Nqqhh8oEcQBmMs6U1eR1Ddfo7fytJJ7roL95JPqr9KjTgDiNB2v7gTldVUUQEzUCmJHh0gxgG1KDJa5W3V-fO~qW91W-LWL0IpmzScEyqTovLax1IB3Fh3Q1xTY9iAT9GlZ7Lm~NCHEkGWW5zcCKrrTkETNSWLDcWVZmeGs-B4y6VE6Maf7-pxSKE54dHyXqz2eW03NeZsTbWBBX72kqwFggKL~HxZhKmSZLWbngtTTzdA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=134762087&ar=5290335&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">On the left, we plot the number of targets retrieved by the two ConvNets and the number of \u2018bona fide\u2019 candidates as a function of the threshold of detection <em>p</em>. On the right, we show the percentage with respect to the total number of retrieved candidates as a function of the threshold of detection <em>p</em>.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=134762088 id=\"134762088\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 THE LinKS SAMPLE CANDIDATES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We define the \u2018Lenses in the Kilo-Degree Survey (LinKS) sample\u2019 as the full sample of 1983 gravitational lens candidates retrieved with <em>p</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.8 and a score from the visual inspection greater than zero. The sample contains five previously confirmed strong lenses (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>; Cabanac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Christensen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and 12 lens candidates discovered in the HSC data (Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>; Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib159\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib159\" data-open=\"bib159\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). This sample also contains the \u2018bona fide\u2019 subsample, composed of the 89 candidates that have a visual inspection score \u226528, which we defined in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a>. We note that by relaxing this inspection score requirement further, e.g. to \u226516 (i.e. the score corresponding to four <em>Maybe a lens</em>), we are able to produce a subsample of 308 candidates. Nonetheless, we opt to define our \u2018bona fide\u2019 sample using the more stringent \u226528 requirement.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Information about the data products provided for the LinKS sample, along with images for each of the 89 \u2018bone fide\u2019 candidates, is provided in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec7\">A</a>. Additional information is also provided at the the LinKS webpage.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn9\" data-open=\"fn9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">9</a></sup></p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=134762091 id=\"134762091\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Candidate properties</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we summarize the main characteristics of the LinKS sample. To enable this analysis, we rely on candidates with known spectroscopic redshift publicly available from Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) Data Release 14 (DR14), Galaxy And Mass Assembly (GAMA) Data Release 3 (DR3), and 2-degree Field Lensing Survey (2dFLenS; Blake et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Abolfathi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Baldry et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We also incorporate accurate multiband colours as measured by the Gaussian Aperture and PSF (<span class=\"small-caps\">gaap</span>) code. Briefly, <span class=\"small-caps\">gaap</span> produces fluxes measured in Gaussian-weighted apertures, which are modified per-source and per-image, so as to produce seeing-independent estimates flux estimates across different observations/bands. The aperture modification calculation requires that the PSF of the image be both homogeneous and Gaussian, and so prior to running <span class=\"small-caps\">gaap</span> each survey tile has its PSF Gaussianized over the full field of view. Importantly, <span class=\"small-caps\">gaap</span> magnitudes are not total, and preferentially weight the central, redder parts of our lens galaxies. This acts to reduce the contamination of the outer (blue) features of the lens candidates (i.e. the lensed arcs), and improve the fidelity of lens candidate spectral energy distribution (SED) models. In this section, we have chosen to limit our analysis to the LinKS sample in the KiDS-North patch.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn10\" data-open=\"fn10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">10</a></sup> This selection reduces our LinKS sample to 659 candidates, of which 41 (out of 89) are in the \u2018bona fide\u2019 subsample. We show the observer-frame <em>g</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>r</em> colour in terms of redshift of these candidates in the left-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. Because of our initial selection criteria (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>) all of our candidates exhibit red colours, with <em>g</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>r</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.8 at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00 and <em>g</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>r</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.7 at the highest redshifts <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.5. Visually the \u2018bone fide\u2019 candidates seem to sample the colour distribution of the entire sample without bias; they are otherwise unexemplary. To further characterize the sample of candidates, and allow for a comparison with the literature, we then estimate stellar masses for the subsample of our sources with spectroscopic redshifts.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn11\" data-open=\"fn11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">11</a></sup> Following Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), we estimate stellar masses using the software <span class=\"small-caps\">Le Phare</span> (Arnouts et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Ilbert et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), which does a \u03c7<sup>2</sup> fitting between colours from stellar population synthesis (SPS) models and the observed colours. We employ single-burst SPS models from Bruzual\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>, BC03) and a Chabrier (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) IMF, allowing the stellar population age to vary and assuming metallicities in the range (0.005\u20132.5\u00a0Z<sub>\u2299</sub>). The maximum age is set by the age of the Universe at the redshift of the galaxy, with a maximum value at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0=\u00a00 of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$13\\, \\rm Gyr$|\u2060</span>. We do not consider internal extinction, and our models assume zero redshift uncertainty. We adopt the <span class=\"small-caps\">gaap</span><em>ugri</em> magnitudes <span class=\"monospace\">mag_gaap</span> and related <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1 \\sigma$|</span> uncertainties (Kuijken et\u00a0al., in preparation), corrected for Galactic extinction using the map by Schlafly\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Finkbeiner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The <em>r</em>-band <span class=\"small-caps\">mag_auto</span> is used to correct the results of <span class=\"small-caps\">Le Phare</span> for missing flux.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn12\" data-open=\"fn12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">12</a></sup> The typical uncertainty on the stellar mass estimates (provided by <span class=\"small-caps\">Le Phare</span>) is \u223c0.1\u20130.2\u00a0dex. Stellar masses are shown as a function of redshift in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, and compared with SLACS (Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and SL2S (Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib125\" data-open=\"bib125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>) data. Consistently with Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), the selected candidates have redshifts in the window <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.1 \\mathrel {\\rlap{\\lower3.5pt\\hbox{${\\sim }$}} {\\lt}}z \\mathrel {\\rlap{\\lower3.5pt\\hbox{${\\sim }$}}\\,{\\lt}}0.5$|\u2060</span>, with a median value of 0.33, while the stellar masses are typically larger than <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10^{11}\\,{\\rm M}_\\odot$|\u2060</span>, with an average value of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim } 2 \\times 10^{11}\\,{{\\rm M}_\\odot}$|\u2060</span>. We note, of course, that the choice of IMF significantly influences the final mass estimates; using a Salpeter (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1955</a>) IMF instead of a Chabrier IMF causes inferred stellar masses to increase by a factor of \u223c2 with no change to observed colours (Tortora et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib142\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib142\" data-open=\"bib142\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). The \u2018bone fide\u2019 candidates are shown in green in both panels. They span a similar range of redshifts and masses as the whole sample, with a marginal indication that they may preferentially sample higher stellar masses.</p>                        <a id=\"134762093\" scrollto-destination=\"134762093\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/m_stz189fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&amp;Signature=DVqWSkAOCPXZzAmKg1~HI06qcaCEH-XAOCdw6QqcM2AaRM0EoL--ozxDUEzzhCl5q0ZeTNsAOz27W0Kj4J-IoBSnlXVJo~juCiotVbRwiUDv419VWLP80DURrfv-s4elKnaJ2HMhKKMEMhbcCeKqzd7pYd6EpatyrW9sVOAcXxFVoQUoT4INebHX~ETqPy4i8gtjS0dVmTZaLwZ3WNhkSb0yDOhzP-7aPPntteK0b0pnRO7Ax9eLMwDxMmjAc2pvWNEsXM8qtTEoMhSi0U9EM--RTgwHcb5ZtSmG9jGXFNaJx9pDXrF8NmZvc0qobVLIuHKDOPos7O-PbX4omSQhbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The g \u2212 r observer-frame colour, corrected for Galactic extinction (left-hand panel) and stellar mass (right-hand panel) versus redshift for a subsample of 659 ConvNet candidates with spectroscopic redshift available (grey dots). The subsample of best candidates with a visual score larger than 28 is shown as green points. Stellar masses (see Section\u00a04.1) are compared with the SLACS sample from Auger et\u00a0al. (2009, red triangles) and the SL2S sample from Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. (2013b, blue squares).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/134762093/stz189fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"134762093\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/stz189fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&Signature=TVfuDIR7oJ0oMqA~~47g1TL3JoZzA3AF~1uC20cUDIxQMa0mrwHo6lbc9iGDe8aEHuqLWgCEiKREIasEXMuV1nRHV75HToYWuERMxhFueg4OStnm~VNlE-nMGYJpplkaET9mAIufFgdzYO9qoVY9CX4Aa8ZBbzWXMeYhGbXtusYzxzP2EMvSKw4NMPiTkrvdsGT-XHAPuIO3STC4shKEAAWlRi0dPaN4rD-U-3jaJ263JOWidiKDs~pbBKa1HNm28DtClNaTA1cfEzmQyC7VcQ6yerqxPjcET5zV2F1Uhay6NYP4AfThiFdFidql3wjoXzpxCxqDvoGZv2Q1BfVCGQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=134762093&ar=5290335&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> observer-frame colour, corrected for Galactic extinction (left-hand panel) and stellar mass (right-hand panel) versus redshift for a subsample of 659 ConvNet candidates with spectroscopic redshift available (grey dots). The subsample of best candidates with a visual score larger than 28 is shown as green points. Stellar masses (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>) are compared with the SLACS sample from Auger et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>, red triangles) and the SL2S sample from Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib125\" data-open=\"bib125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>, blue squares).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/m_stz189fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&amp;Signature=DVqWSkAOCPXZzAmKg1~HI06qcaCEH-XAOCdw6QqcM2AaRM0EoL--ozxDUEzzhCl5q0ZeTNsAOz27W0Kj4J-IoBSnlXVJo~juCiotVbRwiUDv419VWLP80DURrfv-s4elKnaJ2HMhKKMEMhbcCeKqzd7pYd6EpatyrW9sVOAcXxFVoQUoT4INebHX~ETqPy4i8gtjS0dVmTZaLwZ3WNhkSb0yDOhzP-7aPPntteK0b0pnRO7Ax9eLMwDxMmjAc2pvWNEsXM8qtTEoMhSi0U9EM--RTgwHcb5ZtSmG9jGXFNaJx9pDXrF8NmZvc0qobVLIuHKDOPos7O-PbX4omSQhbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The g \u2212 r observer-frame colour, corrected for Galactic extinction (left-hand panel) and stellar mass (right-hand panel) versus redshift for a subsample of 659 ConvNet candidates with spectroscopic redshift available (grey dots). The subsample of best candidates with a visual score larger than 28 is shown as green points. Stellar masses (see Section\u00a04.1) are compared with the SLACS sample from Auger et\u00a0al. (2009, red triangles) and the SL2S sample from Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. (2013b, blue squares).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/134762093/stz189fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"134762093\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/stz189fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&Signature=TVfuDIR7oJ0oMqA~~47g1TL3JoZzA3AF~1uC20cUDIxQMa0mrwHo6lbc9iGDe8aEHuqLWgCEiKREIasEXMuV1nRHV75HToYWuERMxhFueg4OStnm~VNlE-nMGYJpplkaET9mAIufFgdzYO9qoVY9CX4Aa8ZBbzWXMeYhGbXtusYzxzP2EMvSKw4NMPiTkrvdsGT-XHAPuIO3STC4shKEAAWlRi0dPaN4rD-U-3jaJ263JOWidiKDs~pbBKa1HNm28DtClNaTA1cfEzmQyC7VcQ6yerqxPjcET5zV2F1Uhay6NYP4AfThiFdFidql3wjoXzpxCxqDvoGZv2Q1BfVCGQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=134762093&ar=5290335&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> observer-frame colour, corrected for Galactic extinction (left-hand panel) and stellar mass (right-hand panel) versus redshift for a subsample of 659 ConvNet candidates with spectroscopic redshift available (grey dots). The subsample of best candidates with a visual score larger than 28 is shown as green points. Stellar masses (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>) are compared with the SLACS sample from Auger et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>, red triangles) and the SL2S sample from Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib125\" data-open=\"bib125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>, blue squares).</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=134762094 id=\"134762094\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Predictions and prospects: <em>Euclid</em> and LSST</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Using the <span class=\"small-caps\">LensPop</span> code presented in Collett (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) estimated that the maximally retrievable number of strong lens candidates in a fully complete KiDS survey would be \u223c2400. For a \u223c900\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> area such as that considered in this paper, ignoring the masked area of the survey, we would there expect to find \u223c1700 possible strong lenses. If we further consider only those lenses that satisfy our LRG colour\u2013magnitude cuts (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>), and which have an Einstein radius larger than 1\u00a0arcsec (i.e. the range on which the ConvNets have been trained; see table\u00a01 in Petrillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), this number reduces further to about \u223c450 retrievable strong lenses. Their average distribution in redshift is consistent with the actual distribution of our retrieved candidates of the previous subsection, peaking at a value of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.3. Our samples here therefore fully encompass the predicted \u223c450 retrievable strong lenses from <span class=\"small-caps\">LensPop</span>: the full sample of LinKS candidates containing \u223c4\u00d7 the number of predicted sources, and the bone fide sample containing \u223c5\u00d7 too few. We note again, though, that by relaxing the visual inspection score requirement to e.g. \u226516 (the score corresponding to four <em>Maybe a lens</em>) one can create a wider \u2018bone fide\u2019 sample containing 308 candidates; \u223c68\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the retrievable lenses predicted by <span class=\"small-caps\">LensPop</span>. Nonetheless, we continue to conservatively consider only the 89 sources in our \u2018bona fide\u2019 subsample to be genuine lenses, and conclude that this sample is complete at the level of \u223c20\u00a0per\u00a0cent.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the following, we predict the number of lenses expected in future surveys utilizing the depth and breadth of the future <em>Euclid</em> and Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) surveys, and the performance of our ConvNets in retrieving strong lenses within these future data sets.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Euclid</em>. Collett (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) predicts that there will be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim } 170\\, 000$|</span> potential lenses in <em>Euclid</em>. Petrillo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) extended this analysis by estimating the number of lenses with an Einstein radius larger than 1\u00a0arcsec and with a redshift <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.5, which roughly corresponds to our LRG colour cut selection. This reduces the number of potential strong lenses to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }20\\, 000$|</span> in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$15\\, 000$|</span>\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> of the completed survey. With the same strategy used in this paper, we conservatively estimate that between \u223c5000 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }15\\, 000$|</span> lenses will be retrievable with ConvNets from the completed <em>Euclid</em> survey. These numbers assume that the one-band ConvNet performs at least as well on <em>Euclid</em> data as it does on KiDS data, in the same parameter domain, and that it is possible to pre-select LRGs with the aid of ground-based multiband observations and the IR bands from <em>Euclid</em>. We note, though, that <em>Euclid</em> data will have better image quality than KiDS, which will allow the training of more effective algorithms over a wider parameter space. Furthermore, it will allow improved recognition and rejection of false positives via visual inspection. These considerations all lead to our assessment that our estimate of the number of retrievable strong lenses is conservative.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>LSST</em>. The above forecast can also be performed for LSST, and moreover with greater accuracy, as LSST will observe in the same <em>g, r</em>, and <em>i</em> filters as does KiDS. We find that the number of potentially discoverable lenses in LSST, with an Einstein radius larger than 1\u00a0arcsec and with our invoked LRG colour selection, is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }20\\, 000$|</span> over the 20\u00a0000\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> of the completed survey. Therefore, as in <em>Euclid</em>, we estimate that between \u223c5000 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }15\\, 000$|</span> lenses may be retrievable from the completed LSST survey data with our ConvNets.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=134762099 id=\"134762099\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 THE FULL SAMPLE CANDIDATES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Visual inspection of strong lens candidates selected by the ConvNets is a time-consuming task. However investing such time to achieve increased purity and completeness of the recovered candidate sample is worth the effort. But lowering the <em>p</em>-value threshold above which lens candidates are defined, or significantly increasing the survey area (and thus significantly increasing the absolute number of <em>p</em>\u00a0\u2265\u00a00.8 candidates) naturally only exacerbates this task. As such, performing the visual inspections completed here for much larger target samples, such as those expected from <em>Euclid</em> and LSST, will likely be prohibitive. In these cases, one may want to reduce the number of candidates to visually inspect by increasing the <em>p</em>-threshold required for candidacy definition. However, it is unclear how such an increase may influence the number of lens candidates returned. Furthermore, if the scientific aim is to establish a complete strong lens sample that is unbiased in its lens properties, then such a high threshold may be counter-productive. The <em>LRG sample</em> used in this paper is a distinct subsample of massive early-type galaxies (ETGs) that lack (active) star formation and therefore have profiles that allow easier separation of foreground lenses from lensed images, which are often blue star-forming galaxies, as demonstrated in SLACS. In this work, we use the LRG sample because we expect most of the lenses to be massive ETGs. However, selecting such a sample of galaxies is not always straightforward and can lead to the loss of potential lenses; LRGs do not represent the entire population of galaxies and hence the entire strong lensing cross-section.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For this reason, it is interesting to see how the ConvNets perform on a less restricted and much larger sample of galaxies. We explore these issues in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a> by applying the ConvNets to the <em>full sample</em>, but with a higher threshold in <em>p</em>, in order to reduce the visual inspection effort. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2</a>, we then translate the outcome to the planned <em>Euclid</em> and LSST surveys and analyse the advantages and applicability of such a strategy. Finally, in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.3</a>, we present a composite sample of lens candidates collected from various ConvNets, applied to the <em>full sample</em>, that were run during the ConvNet optimisation process. Each of these runs was less efficient than the final ConvNets employed in the main body of this work, but sometimes yielded distinct lenses that we have subsequently collated.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=134762102 id=\"134762102\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 A high-purity sample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We run the two ConvNets on the <em>full sample</em> (930\u2009651 galaxies) rather than on the smaller but purer <em>LRG sample</em> (88\u2009327 galaxies). To obtain a sample of lens candidates that is both pure and limited in size, and in order to reduce the visual inspection load, we average the predictions from both ConvNets into a single predictive parameter <em>p</em>. We select candidates with an average value of <em>p</em> larger than 0.999. With this selection we obtain just 30 strong lens candidates (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>); 0.003\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the <em>full sample</em>. When visually inspected, we find that this sample is extremely pure and, more in particular, it is composed of<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn13\" data-open=\"fn13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">13</a></sup><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">two confirmed lenses (Cabanac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>);</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">one candidate discovered by Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>);</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">one quad recently identified by Sergeyev et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>);</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">14 very-likely genuine lenses;</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">10 potential lenses;</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">two possible contaminants.</p></li></ul></p>                        <a id=\"134762104\" scrollto-destination=\"134762104\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/m_stz189fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&amp;Signature=b10zoryIq1XF0ZfQB52PB33n5g~c8WJXPGiDhDwzrhAFSPucI25myC708rsq54gWQUvvZ92OG9dn3iKXohTcIdb59RFobb5bh5p5TzyrsKG2u3YgVFeKwgPW9i8eYxylbjbhyBaVwJBUu-dAMp~PcFduVJcynjesdGwknVTcPO9Nm8N6FOyCIxoWZULLBGs7gDUwoj1NF~py4pXvzA4QUWxl4XVaYbgPSWJ-LJi-z4ppeM7Eq6Efrw3kqZR4KylLcAWISYJRPrlqxyYKj8bHwrJD~PZiqCuvnjArFuFOawnLR7FIDfZdUHvMua8eKsOX823P1o3krFTWRwVsh2G3Fw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Images of the sample of candidates retrieved running the two ConvNets on the full sample, averaging the predictions and selecting those with p\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.999. This sample is &gt;90\u00a0per\u00a0cent pure and requires very little human intervention. The upper block of 12 galaxies is part of the LRG sample, while the bottom 18 galaxies are exclusively part of the full sample. More information on the latter candidates can be found in Appendix A. Each image has dimensions 20\u00a0\u00d7\u00a020\u00a0arcsec2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/134762104/stz189fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"134762104\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/stz189fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&Signature=DOjWfZ4bDKpU68g4~12O8bTezXXfH2AzQIoPfPIKvBj76b00vWr7cHQTk0SKlOVh4SYYK0yk40XqlkEamJpUWE46YKJO1mpUDFgd9DEwXZ-L4rflSywP95SKPHYdG9DvTTBfMjE0h24IIckG0w2GEia6nhSqv36uA5Hj2PnCanLJGR7fLHwLdxLuenOrCPxTHT~dzohte4fgQm~kwKScdfTXtyM-sVal7H1D0omnNvFmTn32NNVb1~dXVf~uI7s3PwEQ3M1UPwSuoPwCVmIO2PJqHulvAlqXWdHpGIvdbjf2OH6wkyEIu9HHcYVTiJhPzI6bjOgwpjtuIQTGptVg4w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=134762104&ar=5290335&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Images of the sample of candidates retrieved running the two ConvNets on the <em>full sample</em>, averaging the predictions and selecting those with <em>p</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.999. This sample is &gt;90\u00a0per\u00a0cent pure and requires very little human intervention. The upper block of 12 galaxies is part of the <em>LRG sample</em>, while the bottom 18 galaxies are exclusively part of the <em>full sample</em>. More information on the latter candidates can be found in Appendix A. Each image has dimensions 20\u00a0\u00d7\u00a020\u00a0arcsec<sup>2</sup>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/m_stz189fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&amp;Signature=b10zoryIq1XF0ZfQB52PB33n5g~c8WJXPGiDhDwzrhAFSPucI25myC708rsq54gWQUvvZ92OG9dn3iKXohTcIdb59RFobb5bh5p5TzyrsKG2u3YgVFeKwgPW9i8eYxylbjbhyBaVwJBUu-dAMp~PcFduVJcynjesdGwknVTcPO9Nm8N6FOyCIxoWZULLBGs7gDUwoj1NF~py4pXvzA4QUWxl4XVaYbgPSWJ-LJi-z4ppeM7Eq6Efrw3kqZR4KylLcAWISYJRPrlqxyYKj8bHwrJD~PZiqCuvnjArFuFOawnLR7FIDfZdUHvMua8eKsOX823P1o3krFTWRwVsh2G3Fw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Images of the sample of candidates retrieved running the two ConvNets on the full sample, averaging the predictions and selecting those with p\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.999. This sample is &gt;90\u00a0per\u00a0cent pure and requires very little human intervention. The upper block of 12 galaxies is part of the LRG sample, while the bottom 18 galaxies are exclusively part of the full sample. More information on the latter candidates can be found in Appendix A. Each image has dimensions 20\u00a0\u00d7\u00a020\u00a0arcsec2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/134762104/stz189fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"134762104\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/stz189fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&Signature=DOjWfZ4bDKpU68g4~12O8bTezXXfH2AzQIoPfPIKvBj76b00vWr7cHQTk0SKlOVh4SYYK0yk40XqlkEamJpUWE46YKJO1mpUDFgd9DEwXZ-L4rflSywP95SKPHYdG9DvTTBfMjE0h24IIckG0w2GEia6nhSqv36uA5Hj2PnCanLJGR7fLHwLdxLuenOrCPxTHT~dzohte4fgQm~kwKScdfTXtyM-sVal7H1D0omnNvFmTn32NNVb1~dXVf~uI7s3PwEQ3M1UPwSuoPwCVmIO2PJqHulvAlqXWdHpGIvdbjf2OH6wkyEIu9HHcYVTiJhPzI6bjOgwpjtuIQTGptVg4w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=134762104&ar=5290335&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz189fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Images of the sample of candidates retrieved running the two ConvNets on the <em>full sample</em>, averaging the predictions and selecting those with <em>p</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.999. This sample is &gt;90\u00a0per\u00a0cent pure and requires very little human intervention. The upper block of 12 galaxies is part of the <em>LRG sample</em>, while the bottom 18 galaxies are exclusively part of the <em>full sample</em>. More information on the latter candidates can be found in Appendix A. Each image has dimensions 20\u00a0\u00d7\u00a020\u00a0arcsec<sup>2</sup>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">This result attests to the capability of the ConvNets to find lens candidates in a sample slightly different from what it was trained on. We note that 18 of the 30 candidates retrieved in this manner are not part of the <em>LinKS sample</em> because they did not satisfy the LRG cut in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.3</a> for more information on these candidates). We note further that it is entirely possible that some of these candidates fail our LRG colour\u2013magnitude selection explicitly because of contamination by the bright blue lensing features that we are attempting to locate; a clear drawback of such an LRG selection with imperfect photometry.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=134762106 id=\"134762106\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Small high-purity <em>Euclid</em>\u00a0and LSST samples</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Considering that, theoretically, the number of recoverable lenses in \u223c900\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> of KiDS is at most \u223c1700 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>), our recovery of only 30 candidates in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a> implies that a <em>p</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.999 set-up will only recover \u223c2\u00a0per\u00a0cent of possibly retrievable lenses. If we turn this efficiency into a forecast for the 170\u2009000 total retrievable lenses in the full <em>Euclid</em> survey as predicted by Collett (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), we expect to find \u223c3000 candidates with a &gt;90\u00a0per\u00a0cent purity that are retrievable with minimal human intervention. Such a sample represents the often called \u2018low-hanging fruit\u2019 of strong lenses within <em>Euclid</em>, as these sources are expected to occupy a limited but easily accessible part of parameter space (i.e. large Einstein radii and low redshifts). Note again that we expect this number to be conservative, as with our other forecasts presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>, as <em>Euclid</em> lenses will be observed with a much higher angular resolution than KiDS lenses, and will be detected with ConvNets trained on higher fidelity data. Near-IR colours will also help to downselect lens candidates since, being less sensitive to the dust and mapping a wider wavelength baseline, they will provide a more efficient way to separate LRGs from star-forming galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Nonetheless, even in this conservative case, the number of lenses forecast here would be one to two orders of magnitude larger than the number detected in any previous or ongoing strong lens survey. Finally, as in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>, a similar number of easy candidates may be expected from LSST surveys.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=134762109 id=\"134762109\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>5.3 The \u2018bonus sample\u2019</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The sample presented in this section includes 200 strong lens candidates discovered serendipitously during previous ConvNet runs that are not part of the LinKS sample. The candidates in this <em>bonus sample</em> have not gone through the same rigorous visual inspection as those in the LinKS sample, and subsequently cannot be considered to be as statistically well defined. However, if we apply the ConvNets to these candidates with a threshold <em>p</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.8, 160 candidates pass this threshold in at least one of the two ConvNets, i.e. 80\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the sample. Detailed data related to this sample can be found online<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn14\" data-open=\"fn14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">14</a></sup> (see Appendix A). This sample contains eight HSC survey lens candidates (Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>) and four confirmed lenses: J1452\u22120058 (Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), J142449\u2212005322 (Tanaka et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib138\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib138\" data-open=\"bib138\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), J010127\u2212334319 (Bettinelli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), and KiDS\u00a00239\u22123211 (Sergeyev et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=134762111 id=\"134762111\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present several samples of lens candidates from the KiDS that likely contain several hundred strong gravitational lenses. To generate these samples, we apply two new lens-finder algorithms \u2013 based on ConvNets \u2013 to a sample of 88\u2009327 LRGs, selected via a colour\u2013magnitude cut, from 904 one-deg<sup>2</sup> tiles of KiDS data. We visually inspect the candidates selected by these ConvNets and conservatively select 1983 rank-ordered candidates, which we designate the <em>LinKS sample</em> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>). We further subset the data into subsamples of 219 more plausible candidates, and 89 highly likely candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We did not attempt to achieve a high level of statistical completeness in the samples of LRGs, nor in the samples of resulting lens candidates. We aimed instead to both maximize the number of lens candidates while minimizing the fraction of false positives. Our colour\u2013magnitude selection (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>) aimed at choosing a large sample of massive (early-type) galaxies while specifically avoiding star-forming (e.g. spiral) galaxies and other contaminants. We note that Vakili et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib152\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib152\" data-open=\"bib152\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) recently selected LRGs from KiDS data using the LRG colour\u2013magnitude relation, and also computed their photometric redshifts; we anticipate that this sample could be utilized to compile a more statistically complete sample of KiDS LRG lens candidates in the future. In addition to the <em>LinKS sample</em>, in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.3</a>, we presented a <em>bonus sample</em> that consists of 200 lens candidates. These lenses were serendipitously discovered in KiDS data, e.g. during previous experiments with various ConvNets. While these sources have not been rigorously scrutinized in the same manner as our main LinKS sample, and we therefore do not consider it to be as statistically well defined as our main sample, it none the less contains a number of interesting strong lens candidates for future follow-up.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From our KiDS strong lens candidates (together with those found by Hartley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a> and Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib132\" data-open=\"bib132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), the \u223c600 galaxy-scale lens candidates found in DES (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Jacobs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib133\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib133\" data-open=\"bib133\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) and HSC data (Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>; Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib159\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib159\" data-open=\"bib159\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), it will soon be possible to select a sample of confirmed lenses similar in size to the total number of gravitational lenses known today. For example the Masterlens data base,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn15\" data-open=\"fn15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">15</a></sup> which assembles information on all known gravitational lenses, contains a total of \u223c600 gravitational lenses discovered up to 2016. It is possible that the total number could be, by now, up to \u223c1000 confirmed lenses and lens candidates. We believe it likely that strong lens searches within the KiDS, DES, and HSC surveys could easily double this number \u2013 accumulated over many decades \u2013 within the next few years.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Despite the already considerable numbers of new lens candidates from KiDS, there are still many lens candidates to be discovered, especially in that part of parameter space that we have not, or rather not thoroughly, explored. In addition, the completed KiDS survey will cover an area of 1350\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>. We plan to apply our method to these completed KiDS data, together with that of Spiniello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib132\" data-open=\"bib132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), to find lensed quasars. Applying other complementary methods as Hartley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) SVM will aid in maximizing the exploration of the parameter space.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Besides the LRG-selected sample, we have shown that is possible to tune the ConvNets to yield a sample of lens candidates with considerable purity by using many more targets (i.e. about 10 times more). In particular, we ran the lens finders on a sample composed of 930\u2009651 galaxies (not just LRGs) and retrieved a sample of 30 strong lens candidates with an expected purity of &gt;90\u00a0per\u00a0cent. By selecting lens candidates in this way, we are able to considerably diminish the visual inspection load, although at the price of losing many genuine lenses. With a similar set-up, though, it would be feasible to retrieve \u223c3000 lens candidates from the future <em>Euclid</em> data set with minimal human intervention. A similar number would be found by LSST.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All these results can be enhanced further, especially by training the ConvNets with more complete training sets (Petrillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). In addition, a collection of genuine lens candidates, even in modest numbers, should allow one to fine-tune ConvNet lens finders further to improve their classification capacity (Tuccillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib150\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib150\" data-open=\"bib150\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Dom\u00ednguez S\u00e1nchez et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). New gravitational lenses can also be used as training sets for future crowdsourced searches (Marshall et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Finally, the candidates identified in this paper could be used to build a benchmark against which different lens finders can be tested and compared, similar to analyses done with simulated data (e.g. Metcalf et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our results are very encouraging in light of future strong lens surveys (e.g. those utilising <em>Euclid</em> and LSST) for which a naive strategy of visually inspecting galaxies to select lens candidates is entirely infeasible, given the enormous number of galaxies these new instruments will uncover. One can expect to compile samples of strong lenses from <em>Euclid</em> and LSST that are between one to two orders of magnitude larger than the samples compiled by any survey to date, and with minimal human effort.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=134762119 id=\"134762119\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The authors are grateful to the referee Alessandro Sonnenfeld for the thorough and helpful comments. CEP thanks Leon Doddema, Martin Vogelaar, and Ewout Helmich for help and support. CEP, CT, GV, and LVEK are supported through an NWO-VICI grant (project number 639.043.308). CT also acknowledges funding from the INAF PRIN-SKA 2017 program 1.05.01.88.04. SC has been financially supported by a grant (project number 614.001.206) from the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research (NWO). GVK acknowledges financial support from the Netherlands Research School for Astronomy (NOVA) and Target. Target is supported by Samenwerkingsverband Noord Nederland, European fund for regional development, Dutch Ministry of economic affairs, Pieken in de Delta, Provinces of Groningen and Drenthe. NRN acknowledges financial support from the European Union Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under the Marie Sklodowska-Curie grant agreement no. 721463 to the SUNDIAL ITN network. This work is supported by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft in the framework of the TR33 \u2018The Dark Universe\u2019. MB is supported by the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research, NWO, through grant number 614.001.451 and by the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education through grant DIR/WK/2018/12. BG acknowledges support from the European Research Council under grant number 647112. JTAdJ is supported by the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research (NWO) through grant 621.016.402. CH acknowledges support from the European Research Council under grant number 647112. KK acknowledges support by the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation. CS has received funding from the European Union\u2019s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under the Marie Sklodowska-Curie actions grant agreement No 664931. This work is based on data products from observations made with ESO Telescopes at the La Silla Paranal Observatory under programme IDs 177.A-3016, 177.A-3017, and 177.A-3018, and on data products produced by Target/OmegaCEN, INAF-OACN, INAF-OAPD, and the KiDS production team, on behalf of the KiDS consortium. OmegaCEN and the KiDS production team acknowledge support by NOVA and NWO-M grants. Members of INAF-OAPD and INAF-OACN also acknowledge the support from the Department of Physics and Astronomy of the University of Padova, and of the Department of Physics of University of Federico II (Naples). GAMA is a joint European\u2013Australasian project based around a spectroscopic campaign using the Anglo-Australian Telescope. The GAMA input catalogue is based on data taken from the SDSS and the UKIDSS. Complementary imaging of the GAMA regions is being obtained by a number of independent survey programmes including <em>GALEX</em> MIS, VST KiDS, VISTA VIKING, <em>WISE, Herschel</em>-ATLAS, GMRT, and ASKAP, providing ultraviolet to radio coverage. GAMA is funded by the STFC (UK), the ARC (Australia), the AAO, and the participating institutions. The GAMA website is <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.gama-survey.org\" target=\"_blank\">www.gama-survey.org</a>. Funding for the Sloan Digital Sky Survey IV has been provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the US Department of Energy Office of Science, and the Participating Institutions. SDSS acknowledges support and resources from the Center for High-Performance Computing at the University of Utah. The SDSS web site is <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.sdss.org\" target=\"_blank\">www.sdss.org</a>. SDSS is managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions of the SDSS Collaboration including the Brazilian Participation Group, the Carnegie Institution for Science, Carnegie Mellon University, the Chilean Participation Group, the French Participation Group, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias, The Johns Hopkins University, Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe (IPMU)/University of Tokyo, the Korean Participation Group, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Leibniz Institut f\u00fcr Astrophysik Potsdam (AIP), Max-Planck-Institut fur Astronomie (MPIA Heidelberg), Max-Planck-Institut fur Astrophysik (MPA Garching), Max-Planck-Institut fur Extraterrestrische Physik (MPE), National Astronomical Observatories of China, New Mexico State University, New York University, University of Notre Dame, Observatorio Nacional/MCTI, The Ohio State University, Pennsylvania State University, Shanghai Astronomical Observatory, United Kingdom Participation Group, Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, University of Arizona, University of Colorado Boulder, University of Oxford, University of Portsmouth, University of Utah, University of Virginia, University of Washington, University of Wisconsin, Vanderbilt University, and Yale University. The <span class=\"small-caps\">topcat</span> (Taylor <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib139\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib139\" data-open=\"bib139\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) and <span class=\"small-caps\">stilts</span> (Taylor <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib140\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib140\" data-open=\"bib140\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) software have been extensively used in this project. <em>Author Contributions:</em> all authors contributed to the development and writing of this paper. The authorship list is given in three groups: the lead authors (CEP, CT, GV, LVEK, GVK), followed by two alphabetical groups. The first alphabetical group includes those who are key contributors to both the scientific analysis and the data products. The second group covers those who have either made a significant contribution to the data products, or to the scientific analysis.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=134762121 id=\"134762121\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Not all of these lenses have been spectroscopically confirmed though, but from their image geometry are extremely probable to be strong lenses.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div analysis to the first 904 tiles that were processed by Astro-WISE.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn6\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn7\" class=\"end-note-link\">7</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Larger images require a larger numbers of network weights and consequently more computer memory.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn8\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn8\" class=\"end-note-link\">8</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.astromatic.net/software/stiff\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.astromatic.net/software/stiff</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn9\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn9\" class=\"end-note-link\">9</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.astro.rug.nl/lensesinkids\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.astro.rug.nl/lensesinkids</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn10\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn10\" class=\"end-note-link\">10</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The fourth KiDS data release consists of multiband <span class=\"small-caps\">gaap</span> catalogues for both the northern and southern patches, but we chose to limit our analysis to a preliminary set of 497 tiles that were processed by Astro-WISE at the start of this analysis. We note that some improvements have been made to the <span class=\"small-caps\">gaap</span> catalogues during the course of this work, in particular the calibration of the <em>u</em>-band zero-points has been refined. We do not expect these updates to significantly impact our conclusions.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn11\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn11\" class=\"end-note-link\">11</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Robust stellar masses are available from the literature for those KiDS galaxies that are also contained in SDSS and GAMA. However, in order to have homogeneous results for all the candidates, we determine the masses for the whole sample using KiDS four-band photometry.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn12\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn12\" class=\"end-note-link\">12</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><span class=\"small-caps\">gaap</span> magnitudes do not trace the whole galaxy light distribution, for this reason we need to correct the stellar masses <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log M_{\\rm \\star }^{\\rm{L}{\\small E}\\,{P}{\\small HARE}}$|</span> for missing flux, using the following formula <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log M_{\\rm \\star } = \\log M_{\\rm \\star }^{\\rm {L}{\\small E}\\,{P}{\\small HARE}} + 0.4({{\\text {MAG_GAAP_r}}}-{{\\text{MAG_AUTO_r}}})$|\u2060</span>. This could contaminate the lens mass estimate but, since the lensed sources are usually blue, the impact on <span class=\"small-caps\">mag_auto</span>_r is usually small.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn13\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn13\" class=\"end-note-link\">13</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">This sample has been visually inspected using a classification scheme similar to, but not the same as, the one adopted for the LinKS sample. For sake of brevity, we omit details about this classification.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn14\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn14\" class=\"end-note-link\">14</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.astro.rug.nl/lensesinkids\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.astro.rug.nl/lensesinkids</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn15\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn15\" class=\"end-note-link\">15</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://masterlens.astro.utah.edu/\" target=\"_blank\">http://masterlens.astro.utah.edu/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn16\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn16\" class=\"end-note-link\">16</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.astro.rug.nl/lensesinkids\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.astro.rug.nl/lensesinkids</a></p></div></span></div>                    <h2 class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.3847/1538-4357/aae381\" </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib160\" data-legacy-id=\"bib160\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib160\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib160\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib160\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Xu</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">B.</div></span> et al.\u00a0</span>, <div class=\"year\">2016</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">817</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">85</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.3847/0004-637X/817/2/85\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.3847/0004-637X/817/2/85</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.3847/0004-637X/817/2/85\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.3847%2F0004-637X%2F817%2F2%2F85\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.3847%2F0004-637X%2F817%2F2%2F85\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=134762140 id=\"134762140\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>APPENDIX A: DATA</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=134762141 id=\"134762141\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-1>A1 LinKS sample</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the online material<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn16\" data-open=\"fn16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">16</a></sup> we provide a table of our lens candidates properties, with <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">an internal ID;</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">a score from the visual inspection;</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">the <em>p</em>-values from the ConvNets;</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">the lens-candidate coordinates;</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">a flag that indicates whether the candidate is already a confirmed lens or it has been identified as a candidate in other surveys.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition, at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.astro.rug.nl/lensesinkids\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.astro.rug.nl/lensesinkids</a> we list for each one of the 1983 <em>LinKS</em> candidates: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">the internal ID;</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">the visual inspection score;</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">the lens-candidate coordinates;</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">the RGB stamp of 101\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0101\u00a0pixels, corresponding to \u223c20\u00a0\u00d7\u00a020\u00a0arcsec<sup>2</sup>;</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">a link to download their respective <em>g, r</em>, and <em>i</em><span class=\"small-caps\">fits</span> files.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The candidates are ordered by decreasing visual-inspection score. We also present the RGB images of the 89 \u2018bona fide\u2019 candidates in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa1\" data-open=\"figa1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"134762145\" scrollto-destination=\"134762145\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figa1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/484/3/10.1093_mnras_stz189/2/m_stz189figa1a.jpeg?Expires=1611465236&amp;Signature=gFjel~1EpCgLiNXybmfNuA-eeYTj-UCai78FPyzb7HciREKRYL8Xa7SW6gSVV4UMpyQe9ZjOkGRXeAMy5fA4VA~oLjins1IYGY8pjBT52rG~HbmP1~I4hnJor9DH4075UJdTEFndzwKWGVxm2WVn1UCLv6qcbBXLJxGQp6MYS-pZgkYoeaj4rqPrylMi8LiNIwcANaeu5Xu2U9wx--TOg5rsH0Q09ZvgS1Uxq6O6v95wh8ZEEzqJSUyEdU6wZe-ddYXIzWBCqo9ClO18EmthOIlVyWEwuCE3oJlO0UdH17lsRqmqV8ry11~xyQHGv4g4kxJ~lLwqAz5rNxD0ST7hPw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Images of the 89 candidates in the LinKS with a visual-inspection score greater than 27. Each image has dimensions 20\u00a0\u00d7\u00a020\u00a0arcsec<sup>2</sup>.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=134762146 id=\"134762146\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-2>A2 Bonus sample</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>bonus sample</em> is available via <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.astro.rug.nl/lensesinkids\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.astro.rug.nl/lensesinkids</a> similarly to the <em>LinKS sample</em>.</p>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n\r\n        \r\n<div class=\"copyright copyright-statement\">\u00a9 The Author(s) 2019. Univ. Monte S. Angelo, I-80126 Napoli, Italy), AJ(Leiden Observatory, Leiden University, PO Box 9513, NL-2300 RA Leiden, the Netherlands), AK(Argelander-Institut f\u00fcr Astronomie, Auf dem H\u00fcgel 71, D-53121 Bonn, Germany), AL(INAF - Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello 16, I-80131 Napoli, Italy), AM(Institute for Astronomy, University of Edinburgh, Royal Observatory, Blackford Hill, Edinburgh EH9 3HJ, UK), AN(Institute for Astronomy, University of Edinburgh, Royal Observatory, Blackford Hill, Edinburgh EH9 3HJ, UK), AO(Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen, Postbus 800, NL-9700 AV Groningen, the Netherlands), AP(Leiden Observatory, Leiden University, PO Box 9513, NL-2300 RA Leiden, the Netherlands), AQ(Argelander-Institut f\u00fcr Astronomie, Auf dem H\u00fcgel 71, D-53121 Bonn, Germany), AR(Shanghai Astronomical Observatory (SHAO), Nandan Road 80, Shanghai 200030, China), AS(INAF - Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello 16, I-80131 Napoli, Italy), AT(Argelander-Institut f\u00fcr Astronomie, Auf dem H\u00fcgel 71, D-53121 Bonn, Germany)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "484", "publication_year": "2019/04/1", "start_page": "3879", "end_page": "3896", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "galaxies: elliptical and lenticular", "cD", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019MNRAS.484.3879P", "abstract": "We present a new sample of galaxy-scale strong gravitational lens candidates, selected from 904 deg<SUP>2</SUP> of Data Release 4 of the Kilo-Degree Survey, i.e. the `Lenses in the Kilo-Degree Survey' (LinKS) sample. We apply two convolutional neural networks (ConvNets) to {\u223c }88 000 colour-magnitude-selected luminous red galaxies yielding a list of 3500 strong lens candidates. This list is further downselected via human inspection. The resulting LinKS sample is composed of 1983 rank-ordered targets classified as `potential lens candidates' by at least one inspector. Of these, a high-grade subsample of 89 targets is identified with potential strong lenses by all inspectors. Additionally, we present a collection of another 200 strong lens candidates discovered serendipitously from various previous ConvNet runs. A straightforward application of our procedure to future Euclid or Large Synoptic Survey Telescope data can select a sample of \u223c3000 lens candidates with less than 10 per cent expected false positives and requiring minimal human intervention.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stz189", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1812.03168", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "3"}}
